UoY student on the reality of being nightclub door staff

22/11/2022

Nouse talks to Economics student, Will Gray, about what it is like to work on the doors as a student

Image by Peter Malinowski

By James Clay

AS STUDENTS SETTLE into the new academic year and most people have re-immersed themselves within the nightlife of York, Nouse sat down with nightclub doorman and University of York student Will Gray, who works in nightclubs around York.

Although traditionally Willâ€™s job would have generally been referred to as a bouncer, those that work on the door in nightclubs are now most often referred to, within the industry, as door staff. Asked why this is, Will explained that: â€œin the industry, thereâ€™s been a push to move away from the term bouncerâ€ as â€œyou hear the word bouncer and think of a 1970s bouncer who will take you round the corner and kick your teeth in.â€ Whereas now, changes are taking place across the industry, and he notices that at certain venues â€œwe really try to be a friendly door team.â€

Itâ€™s this shift in attitude that has changed the sort of characteristics that security agencies now look for in potential door staff. When asked what sort of characteristics one needs in order to be successful on the door, Will believes that: â€œitâ€™s not about being a 6-foot 8 inch homunculus full of muscle and testosterone replacement therapy.â€ Instead, â€œthereâ€™s a lot of elements to itâ€ as â€œempathy is important, situation awareness, conflict resolution skills and communicationâ€ are priorities.

However, â€œas with anything, it takes a certain kind of person to be good at the jobâ€ as generally â€œthe training is pretty poor, anyone can get a licence.â€ Will also noticed that the role of door staff â€œis also a safeguarding role as we deal with a lot of vulnerable people. Itâ€™s about getting them out safely, rather than just kicking them out.â€

Unfortunately, though, Will accepted that there are door staff who he described as â€œbad applesâ€ due to the fact that they are â€œopenly violent and they abuse their position.â€ Will did say however that this is rare in York when compared to larger cities across the UK. A solution that Will suggested would help root out the â€œbad applesâ€ within the industry is increasing the wage that door staff receive. He argued that: â€œin conjuncture with other measures, getting paid more will make employers more discriminatory.â€

Across many different professions, it is believed that increasing the average pay will encourage skilled and competent door staff to stay within the industry, rather than looking for pay elsewhere. As with many jobs, unfortunately, there is a shortage of trained and willing door staff. Will went on to describe how â€œnowadays, it is a skilled tradeâ€ hence he has received first aid, handcuff, counterterrorism, safeguarding and mental health training.

Fortunately for Will, a lot of this has been paid for by the University of York. Unlike most professions, to become a member of door staff, one has to agree to an exemption from the EU working time directive. Will described how â€œmost companies will make you sign it during the starting processâ€ or one just wouldnâ€™t get the job. As a result, the longest shift that Will has worked began at 7am, ending at 12am.

Reacting to the idea that there should be a union whose purpose it is to represent door staff, Will described how â€œa lot of [door staff] are self-employed, working in an agency, exclusively for one company at a time.â€ Will went onto say that: â€œit is difficult to change thisâ€ so he doubted that a union would ever come into existence.

Despite this lack of industrial representation, Will described how â€œsometimes door staff just walk outâ€ if companies donâ€™t provide adequate pay and support. Usually this will just lead to an immediate sacking and replacement by potentially less skilled employees.

One term commonly used within the nightlife security industry is â€œjacket fillerâ€ which Will explained was a term used to describe â€œindividuals who donâ€™t do anything, they just make up the numbers.â€ This is typically because â€œsome are lazy, some arenâ€™t switched on and some are scared.â€ However, â€œjacket fillersâ€ are usually called out and â€œyou wonâ€™t get any shifts anywhere else.â€ Will also described the stick that one would get from other door staff, particularly if one were to mistakenly kick an innocent individual out of a nightclub.

Asked if he himself ever gets scared, Will admitted that: â€œyou never know what will happen, so you are scaredâ€ when it all kicks off. Despite this, Will stressed that he would always get stuck in and sort out a situation even when substantially outnumbered. This is primarily due to the trust that exists between the staff working during a particular shift.

Will commented: â€œif a member of your team has decided to kick somebody out, you donâ€™t ask why, you back them.â€ Will talked through the procedure for extreme cases in which door staff are so overwhelmingly outnumbered by a large group of violent people. They would send everyone home, lock the doors and wait for the police to arrive. A colleague of Willâ€™s had seen groups numbering as many as 120 men violently attacking one another.

Will also talked further about some of the harder aspects of the job as well, in particular â€œIâ€™ve been spat at, Iâ€™ve had glasses thrown at me and Iâ€™ve had people grab me by the throat.â€ In regard to verbal abuse, Will described how â€œIâ€™ve had people tell me to kill myselfâ€ and that somebody even told him that â€œIâ€™ll rape your nan.â€ This abuse is fairly standard across the industry.

When asked what he would say to students who may be tempted to act in an unruly manner, Will argued that: â€œit is just not worth it.â€ Whether in the context of sexual impropriety or not, being â€œcharged with assault means your life is over.â€ He told Nouse: â€œyou wonâ€™t get a job anywhere with an assault on your record.â€ While working, Will follows a very strict zero tolerance policy towards sexual misconduct, hence, â€œif something happened and you go to the staff, no questions asked, they are gone.â€

On a lighter note, Will commented that: â€œthe biggest misconception is that weâ€™ll know how long it will take to get into the building.â€ Expressed with as light degree of annoyance, Will explained how â€œthatâ€™s the one thing Iâ€™ll get asked every shift and I have no idea.â€ He finished by urging every student that door staff are on the side of students and exist primarily to protect them, rather than to annoy them.
